name: Shuqi Jiang
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For the talk 'Multi-dimensional Test pyramid for microservices' at #AgileTD - your first conference talk ever! It was super insightful to see what you learned in your context. Thanks for sharing your experience with the community!

weblinks.name: Shuqi Jiang [Agile Test Days speaker profile]

name: Samuel Nitsche
note: Nominated by Tobias Geyer: He shared his database development and testing knowledge with a testing audience at Agile Testing Days. Not only was the talk on testing at the database level highly entertaining but it also covered a crucial aspect of testing that's not in everyones mind.

name: Gitte Klitgaard
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For creating and holding a safe space at #AgileTD as well as your talk on choices. You're truly leading by example and I'm continuously learning a lot about myself and the options I have at hand when listening and talking with you. Thank you!

name: Vernon Richards
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For your insightful keynote 'What does the 'Coach' in 'Quality Coach' mean?' at #AgileTD. Loved to learn what's helpful when coaching just as much as the displayed self-reflection on past behavior. Amazing stage performance, delivering important messages in an entertaining way. Thank you!

name: Bruce
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke and Lisi Hocke: Thomas wrote 'Their keynote was probably the best talk I ever saw at a conference, showing ways of being a better ally in tech.' and Lisi wrote 'For the legendary keynote 'How to be an Ally to Non-binary Folk in Tech' at #AgileTD. The extremely important messages stuck and triggered lots of valuable follow-up conversations on these important topics with people. Thousand thanks and huge kudos on your impressive stage performance!'

name: Nithin
note: Nominated by Antonella: I’d like to nominate Nithin and the whole team of Synapse QA for organising Super Reads 2021 and promoting writing in our field.

name: Simon Tomes
note: Nominated by Mirza Sisic: For tirelessly supporting and contributing to the testing community, for being a good conversationalist and one very cool dude!

name: Mark Winteringham and Richard Bradshaw
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for transforming their #AutomationInTesting workshop into a series of #99MinuteWorkshops available for free with a @ministryOfTest pro membership.

name: Emna Ayadi
note: Nominated by Jesper Ottosen: Making a power move to create her evaluation model to better help the teams grow.

name: Kristof Van Kriekingen
note: Nominated by Mirza Sisic: For being cheerful, friendly and always willing to provide helpful answers to other testers - Kristof is never pissed-off!

name: Meg M
note: Nominated by Jesper: The article: 'We are not gatekeepers: A tester's journey for understanding' https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/we-gatekeepers-testers-journey-understanding-meg-mackay/. A reminder that we should build collaboration, rather than break and gatekeep.

name: Menno Bruijn
note: Nominated by Sanne: Menno has been an excellent colleague from day one. His workshop testing blockchain applications was brilliant and he still helps students from the blockchain minor every year next to a busy job. But most importantly always in for a good joke and some fun.

name: Ramona Schwering
note: Nominated by Marcel Schwering: I love the way Ramona teaches on important testing topics. I found her by her awesome articles in Smashing magazine but not only that: She uses drawings and sketch notes in an instructive and cute ways, even in her slides at conferences.

name: Viv Richards
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For creating multiple resources allowing people to discover the potential of the Chrome DevTools, like the Testers Playground and your recent MoT podcast on your course. Thanks, Viv!

name: Sharon O'Boyle
note: Nominated by melissa fisher: Sharon did an inspiring talk at TestFlix on exploring how to use SFDIPOT to learn applications.  A unique presentation in mind map form. Read more about it on Sharon's blog.

weblinks.name: How I use SFDIPOT to learn applications quickly

name: Lisa Crispin
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For her insightful live tweets from conference talks she's attending, this way making the knowledge accessible for people who cannot be there. Years ago this made me want to attend conferences myself and even now I can it's still valuable. Thanks, Lisa!

name: Dimitri Doye
note: Nominated by Emna Ayadi: for bringing the Testing Community of Sogeti Nord together, connecting people having the same testing related challenges in one place, and for the great meetups to inspire testers working on different projects.

name: Angela Riggs
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For her continuous action for a more inclusive and equitable world; sharing resources to help education, calling out bad behavior, sponsoring people, and more. Thank you, Angela!

name: Suman Bala
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Suman has been a bundle of energy since she joined the team and even in her month of getting up to speed, she has helped transform the way we test and making it fun!

name: Jenny Bramble
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: We recently watched one of Jenny’s talks on risk based testing as part of our first Test Party at work and got so much out of it that it has helped us shape the way risk is thought of across the teams.

name: Pricilla Bilavendran
note: Nominated by Praveen David Mathew: Pricilla is a community champion who makes sure to keep the community motivated and inspired . She is always ready to help others by answering technical questions and always ready clap and motivate others in taking up the talks , presentations etc . She always keeps the energy intact within postman and other community channels

name: Emna Ayadi
note: Nominated by Armando Cifuentes González: For always support other testers with her invaluable knowledge :D She rocks!

name: João Proença and Michael Kutz
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: For their insightful #99MinuteWorkshop on cognitive biases and how they affect our thinking and testing.

name: Nishant Gohel
note: Nominated by Jayesh wankhade: Nishant is founder of Fundootesters. He is sharing his knowledge on YouTube with his channel Fundootesters. Helpful in nature and his contribution to community is helping many testers grow and build career in testing. He is also creating meme and making easy learning easy and enjoyable.

name: Christian Kram
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for his (German) talk 'Behavior dropped development' on anti-patterns observable in the application of #BDD as well solution ideas.

name: Andy Hird
note: Nominated by Erin Hess: I nominate Andy because he continues to inspire me to learn and grow as a tester.

name: Stuart Crocker
note: Nominated by Peter Haworth-Langford: An inspirational leader attempting to simplify the understanding of testing for everyone, doing so by challenging, encouraging, being supportive and yet humble. Good luck on your new adventure!

name: Maaret Pyhäjärvi & Ru Cindrea
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For your Racket series 'This Week at Work for Maaret and Ru', sharing deep insights on how everyday work can look like and the manifold ways we can contribute and achieve desired outcomes! Triggering thoughts and inspiring new ideas. Thank you!

weblinks.name: This Week at Work for Maaret and Ru

name: Pricilla & Priyanka
note: Nominated by Nithin: I'd like to celebrate two amazing testers who has created a fantastic learning series on Postman & KarateDSL. The 8 part series of APIs Unleashed is something unique came out from their wonderful efforts to sharing knowledge with the community. It’s an honor to have them in our community and I’d like to make a double nomination to recognize Pricilla Bilavendran and Priyanka Brahmane.

name: Neil Studd
note: Nominated by Beth Marshall: Neil has been on fire the last few weeks - not only co-hosting an incredible new weekly tech podcast but doing an awesome Postman webinar code-along, creating a shared repo for everyone to use. Your hard work is totally paying off Neil - congrats!

name: Nicola I. Martin
note: Nominated by Mike Harris: Nicola is a committee team member for BCS Women and the BCS Special Interest Group in Software Testing (SIGiST). Nicola also mentors for the BCS and AFBE-UK. She is also Head of Education and Mentorship for Women in Tech Global® UK. She recently made the longlist as one of Computer Weekly’s Most Influential Women in UK Tech 2021.

name: Kushan Shalindra Amarasiri
note: Nominated by Dilshani Masachchi: Kushan is a leader in the QA community sharing knowledge with the rest of the world on testing and test automation. He has done over 300 articles on test automation in LinkedIn and also shares lots on knowledge on the subject area which has helped lot of testers to grow.

name: Julia Pottinger
note: Nominated by Antonella Scaravilli: I'd like to nominate Julia Pottinger as tester of the day in order to celebrate her being promoted at work! I think it's very important to have women in leading roles!

name: Maaret Pyhäjärvi
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For initiating and hosting the Exploratory Testing Slack - a great example of how you are continuously working on bringing people together to share experiences, learn with each other, and grow each other to higher levels in a shared welcoming space.

name: Maricel Rodríguez
note: Nominated by Antonella Scaravilli: Maricel was determined to get back into testing but she wanted to refresh what she knew and learn new things. After a year or more of hard work taking courses early in the morning before work and during weekends, she managed to come back to the testing world, which is right where she belongs!!! Congratulations Maricel!!

name: Matías Pírez
note: Nominated by Emna Ayadi: One of the inspiring and successful testers. He started his testing journey by having an accountant background.

weblinks.name: nterview 15: A Software Tester Journey After Being an Accountant

name: Nicola Lindgreen
note: Nominated by Jesper Ottosen: The blogpost that have digged deeper into how the status quo bias makes implementing change rather difficult.

name: Patrick Prill
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For your amazing series of blog posts on test automation and models! Not only are they super insightful and a great reference, they also came very timely as input and resource for a test automation workshop. Thank you! :)

name: Sandeep Garg
note: Nominated by Arlene Andrews: One of the most insightful and welcoming testers I have had the delight of knowing. Not only does Sandeep share suggestions, he discusses them, so both sides can learn.

name: Simon Tomes
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Simon has done an incredible job since becoming communityBoss at MoT. Great to see him so keen to learn so much from the community as well as give back.

name: Ugne Litvinaite
note: Nominated by Chris Armstrong: Ugne is the best hire I ever made, she epitomises critical thinking and curiosity on a daily basis in the workplace. This year she has stepped up, moved out of her comfort zone and is smashing it in her new role as a Senior.

name: Vipin Jain
note: Nominated by Dr. Anubha Jain: Vipin Jain is  testing leader and International speaker. He has presented in 20+ conferences world wide on topics such as IoT, DevOps and Agile. He is a well known process guy who takes pride in setting up processes and make projects process dependent rather than people dependent. He loves to mentor and coach young testers and many of his pupils are established testers. 20+ yeas of varied testing experience makes him my nomination.

name: Geosley Andrades
note: Nominated by Jayesh Wankhade: Great person by heart. Helpful and supportive. Always available to contribute in community. Energetic and Enthusiastic person. His blogs and YouTube videos are really helpful and he shares his knowledge with everyone.

name: Elizabeth Fiennes
note: Nominated by Simon Tomes: Elizabeth is an incredible leader who cares deeply for the well-being of her team. An advocate for removing the pointless and adding what matters. A lovely human. Get to know her if you have the opportunity. You’ll feel inspired after a chat.

name: Butch Mayhew
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Butch did an amazing AMA on test leadership for MoT and then gave some time to have a fantastic Friday afternoon chat with me too. I’ve learned so much from his amazing Rackets too!

name: Ben Dowen
note: Nominated by Sebastian: Does awesome work to foster the testing community, bringing people together and make us thinking how we can improve our craft.

name: Armando Cifuentes
note: Nominated by Antonella Scaravilli: Armando is very active on the Latin American slack channel of MoT and he is the glue of the channel! He has organized some meetups so the members of the channel can hang out and organizing meetings for people in different timezones is challenging but he's doing a great job! Thank you Armando for all the effort and enthusiasm!

name: Ariel Dan
note: Nominated by Stuart Crocker: A few years back, some days were a right struggle, but this guy helped make them bearable. An awesome tester and downright wonderful human, oh and too handsome for his own good!

name: Wouter De Rijck
note: Nominated by Beren Van Daele: A keen eye for problems and a drive to help fix them too! He's a positive teammember who won't shy away from stepping forward and lead the way. Your work is appreciated!

name: Thomas Rinke
note: Nominated by Lisi Hocke: For continuously speaking up and taking action to create more welcoming and safe spaces for everyone, and for sharing his experience on the @TestersIsland podcast.

name: Antoine Craske
note: Nominated by Butel Benjamin: For the whole work you are doing with French, Portuguese and English community : QE Unit, articles, podcasts, videos. https://qeunit.com

name: Alex Schladebeck
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Alex gave an inspiring talk on agile people management at the Brighton MoT meet-up and has shown there is a career pathway in senior leadership for awesome testers!

name: Thomas Rinke
note: Nominated by Neil Studd: For elevating new and diverse voices in the test community, and for doing an immense amount of prep/research for his Testers' Island Discs podcast appearance

name: Simon Prior
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: Nominated for leading discussions on make a tester round table, helping bring the the topic of promoting testing as a career and enabling and his work in reaching out to universities. https://www.linkedin.com/events/6806151118888951808/

name: Benjamin Butel And Emna Ayadi
note: Nominated by Conor Fitzgerald: Translated 'Agile Testing Condensed' to French!

name: Jugal Patil
note: Nominated by Jayesh: Passionate Tester. Community builder. Always ready to share knowledge and help needy ones. Founder of QA Times community. Provide free carrier guidance to many. Active involvement in community activities. Poet and blogger. Good at Liberating Structures.

name: Pankaj Kumar
note: Nominated by Kamlesh Singh: He has build a script of web scrapping with python to fetch all the latest job posted on LinkedIn with job role, organization, job location and job link. It has been helping lot of people to search and apply for job who had lost their job in pandemic.

name: Ryan Dudley
note: Nominated by Jane Kelly: I'm delighted to nominate Ryan, who has been a valued technical support as a real-time automation buddy. Ryan made the time to share skills and experience in relation to trouble shoot the automation code script. Teaming up, cross skilling remotely and optimising knowledge sharing across the miles. Thank you Ryan!

name: Elisabeth Hendrickson
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for her inspiring book 'Explore It!', which provides a wonderful introduction to exploratory testing.

name: Ces Serluca
note: Nominated by Ugne: Ces has been amazing since I started working with him 4 weeks ago. He always finds time to help, is brilliant at explaining things and is just is a good egg. Lucky to be working with someone so nice in the team.

name: Blaise Wielk
note: Nominated by Raquel Bautista: For showing so much enthusiasm, get out his comfort zone and do a great job

name: YOGESH KHAIRNAR
note: Nominated by Jayesh Wankhade: A great person by heart. Always ready to help. The first person who started creating meme on testing. Blogger-QA–QC Arena, actively involved in all most all community events. Creator software testing crossword. A great contributor in testing by his blogs and a great leader.

name: Pablo Soifer
note: Nominated by Juan Martín Altemir: An excellent knowledge and resources divulgator. Great mentoring.

name: Jenna Charlton
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for a wonderful talk about Exploratory Testing at #TestBash Home. Excellent content delivered with passion and an outstanding slide design.

name: Brian McRoberts
note: Nominated by Peet Michielsen: Brian is a stalwart in the Edinburgh testing community. Always up for a coffee chat, cheering everyone up with his choice of tunes. Keep it going

name: Antonella Scaravilli and Ileana Lorena
note: Nominated For being very active and supportive in the Testing community!

name: Erika Chestnut
note: Nominated by Deborah: Such an engaging, fun, interesting Test Bash Home talk!

name: Erin Hess and Jenny Bramble
note: Nominated by Kelly Kenyon: Did an amazing talk on the Empathy is the Foundation of Testing at Test Bash and has made me think a lot about different people and both have amazing blogs

name: Aidan Hourigan
note: Nominated by Bob Salmon: Aidan has exceeded expectations for a long time.  He does a very thorough job, and his bug reports have everything I need to start fixing the problem.

name: Bruce and Chris
note: Nominated by Antonella: I'd like to make a double nomination this time :D I'd like to recognize Bruce and Chris for their double solidarity, staying awake just as Richard is but also staying awake to raise funds.

name: Patrick Prill
note: Nominated by Jesper Ottosen: For the article 'Testing, Quality, and my inability to teach', for spelling out all the different tasks there might be in a tester of today.

name: Vinayak Titti
note: Nominated by Ryan Howard: Vinayak is the co-founder of QA Tech Talks and did a great job arranging the first QA tech talks UK & Europe summit over the weekend. QA tech talks is an incredibly inclusive community for software testers and the whole team did a great job arranging the summit.

name: Peter Haworth-Langford
note: Nominated by Stuart Crocker: It's with a heavy heart that I have to say goodbye to Pete who's heading off to pastures new. He's been there for many years, to listen, to challenge, to support and encourage. I can't imagine my time at ASOS without him being there as a constant. He's the deep-thinking tester, one of the best, definitely one of the most creative. Good luck my friend, you'll smash it.

name: Emna Ayadi
note: Nominated by Mirza Sisic: She's is always interacting with other community members in a kind and a helpful manner and sharing discussions from the Club on the social media.

name: Dinesh Mishra
note: Nominated by Gaurav Chauhan: Thank you Dinesh for always helping me and the testing community. His contribution to the 'learning together' knowledge sharing sessions are awesome and insightful.

name: Rex Jones
note: Nominated by Julia Pottinger: He is an amazing resource for the testing community that has been sharing so much knowledge and helping others on their journey. Really impactful member of the community

name: Joseph Nathan
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Joseph often doesn't get the recognition he deserves for the effort he puts in, covering a very challenging product area and often having to take on more hats than just a Test Manager. He know more about the product area than most in the company and frequently spots things that no one else can spot.

name: Raza Sohail
note: Nominated by Brijesh Deb: Raza has been prolific in fighting against the misconceptions around testing and has bust many myths. He always upholds the dignity of the testing profession

name: Jayesh Wankhade
note: Nominated by Jugal Patil: Part of multiple QA  Communities. Provide Career Guidance and help needy onces in there career. Always ready to provide any help to anyone. Also provide helping hands for getting jobs.

name: Shivkumar Patil
note: Nominated by Krishnanand: Shivkumar brings all the important qualities of a QA to the table. His command over domain puts him way ahead in the league. They say 'put your self in customer shoes', but Shiv does it literally by becoming a full fledged customer and commits to the product.

name: Andy Shaw
note: Nominated by Mike Harris: Andy is the Editor of The Tester magazine. He puts a lot of effort into making sure every issue contains lots of useful articles and information for the testing community.

name: Amrita Pati
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Amrita joined my teams at the start of May and has been a revelation in helping me build the strategy and get on top of all the projects!

name: Danny Dainton
note: Nominated by Praveen David Mathew: Danny keeps on motivating and inspiring community members , his passion for the work he do and the dedication is something to learn from . He always ready to help when ever in need . Keep up the great work Danny you are such an inspiration 🤗

name: Stuart Crocker
note: Nominated by Gareth Waterhouse: For constantly pushing testing forward and helping people see the value in good testing.

name: Ajay Balamurugadas
note: Nominated by Rahul Parwal: Idea Man, Passionate Tester, Helps other reach their dreams and potential, Inspires with his work!

name: Georgina Hughes
note: Nominated by Beth Marshall: Georgina is an awesome person to work with. Talented, helpful and willing to try out new things - including our companies first foray into ensemble exploratory testing!

name: Zagroba
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for a really helpful and excellently hosted #99MinuteWorkshop on Exploratory Testing and Charters during the #ExploratoryWeek

name: Mukesh otwani
note: Nominated by Venkatesh: I connected with Mukesh since 2014 onwards and he is a passionate person to share his knowledge to others and inspiration to all of us. By the way the name Mukesh otwani no need of introduction. Selenium if we search in google it will redirect to Mukesh for sure. Always getting inspired from Mukesh.

name: Maaret Pyhäjärvi
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for her perspectives shared in endless talks and her blog. Her post 'I don't trust your testing and how to change that' offers lots of ideas to improve your testing.

weblinks.name: I don't trust your testing and how to change that

name: Lynda Gaines
note: Nominated by Ben Dowen: Is preventing bugs cheaper then fixing them? Lynda has an article that dives deep on this topic, including pulling out some great details from the well known book 'How Google Tests Software'.

name: Lisi Hocke
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for her excellent workshop 'Ensemble Exploratory Testing' at #GermanTesting Day. Perfectly facilitated, creating a safe space for the participants, supporting our learning.

name: Lee Hawkins
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for being an interesting guest on @TestersIsland sharing insightful perspectives on #ExploratoryTesting and lots of resources on that topic.

name: Jörg Hornung
note: Nominated by Benjamin Bischoff: Jörg has put a lot of effort into making QA at trivago a respected and indispensable part of the development and release process.

name: Huib Schoots
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for delivering another engaging and helpful #99MinuteWorkshop, this time on Storytelling and Test Reporting during the #ExploratoryWeek.

name: Heather Reid
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for supporting #ExploratoryWeek and other events with helpful links & background info and, therefore, taking the sessions to a different level.

name: Edward Kelly
note: Nominated by Ben Dowen: Edward wrote an excellent article Agile Testing, where he gives some great insights into striking a balance between Manual and Automated testing in an Agile environment.

name: David Williams
note: Nominated by Deborah: Guided me through a tough career patch and helped me find my wings and fly :) hope to work with him again one day!

name: Danial Shaw
note: Nominated by Peet Michielsen: I worked with Daniel for almost several years and really appreciated how he advocated for good QA practices in our company. Hope he will continue doing the same in his new place

name: Benjamin Bischoff
note: Nominated by Ben Dowen: Benjamin is consistently contributing to the community, sharing his views and insights on software testing. He has made apprentices in podcasts, his articles have been listed in Software Testing Weekly and gives back in so many other ways!

name: Alex Schladebeck
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for her updated talk on Microheuristics, which was my highlight of the first day of #GermanTesting Day, honored with the best speaker award of the conference.

name: Áine McGovern
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for supporting #ExploratoryWeek and other events with helpful links and background info and, therefore, taking the sessions to a different level.

name: Abby Bangser
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for her interactive and insightful #99MinuteWorkshop on #TestingInProduction. It was fun and led to a better understanding of some concepts around that topic.

name: Simon Tomes
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for being a wonderful guest on the @ministryoftest podcast sharing his passion for #ExploratoryTesting.

name: Peet Michielsen
note: Nominated by melissa fisher: Peet posts a drawing a day on twitter. These drawings are very creative.  They always bring a smile to my face when I see them.

name: Melissa Benua
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for her question about material on BDD. I was looking for perspectives on BDD myself and found really interesting input in this twitter thread.

name: Maaret Pyhäjärvi
note: Nominated by Melissa Fisher: Maaret posts lots of interesting content on twitter and via her blog on exploratory testing.

name: Maaike Brinkhof
note: Nominated by melissa fisher: Maaikee has created a very informative and engaging course on Ministry of Testing on Cognitive Biases in Testing.  Very awesome!!

name: Louise Harney
note: Nominated by melissa fisher: Louise has an excellent blog where she has shared her journey to become a software tester.

weblinks.name: Blog: My journey as an aspiring software tester

name: Jen Kitson
note: Nominated by Georgia Bloyce: For giving an awesome PechaKucha on mistakes people make when writing a test strategy that made me say 'yessss!' with every slide!

name: Naveen Khunteta
note: Nominated by Mukta Sharma: He needs NO introduction as such, because people know him by his famous YouTube channel: 'Naveenautomationlabs'. This channel where there is something to learn for each and every tester around the world. He covers a wide range of technology tools, concept and guidance, covering DevOps, Docker the Cloud and beyond. He has been sharing his vast & in-depth knowledge related to testing with QA community for years. He is inspiration to many people around the globe. Heartiest thanks to you,Naveen From Mukta on behalf of entire QA community.

name: James Espie
note: Nominated by Melissa Fisher: James has written an excellent article on the benefits of a bug bash and how to run one.  Well written and easy to digest for all team members.

weblinks.name: Benefits Of A Bug Bash - And How To Run One

name: Gáspár Nagy
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for his perspectives shared in the @ministryoftest Banglaore online meetup 'Deliberate discovery of requirements with BDD'

weblinks.name: Deliberate discovery of requirements with BDD

name: Faiz Modi
note: Nominated by Sanjay Kumar: Faiz is doing an amazing job as TTC enabler- The Test chat community where tester chat anything. He recognises everyone’s great work & help community by sharing his knowledge & work.

name: Callum Akehurst-Ryan
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for delivering a great #TestingAMA on #ExploratoryTesting, sharing perspectives, providing tips and answering even more questions on The Club.

name: Ashley Hunsberger
note: Nominated by Melissa Fisher: Inspirational discussion on Leading an agile transformation on the Quality Sense podcast.

name: Lina Zubyte
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for being a wonderful guest on @TestersIsland talking about the need for diversity in sw development teams. I really enjoyed this episode.

name: Louise Harney
note: Nominated by Daniel Billing and Simon Tomes: For connecting with the testing community as a positive force for learning and for persevering in difficult times. Louise went from not-a-tester to a tester in about 6 months. And that's just awesome!

name: Huib Schoots
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for delivering an excellent #99MinuteWorkshop on Test Strategies. The Product Coverage Outline hopefully will make a big difference in my project.

name: Himani Jain
note: Nominated by Rahul Singh: Himani has proven to be an effective tester. Her contribution to groom budding testers is exemplary.

name: Brijesh Deb
note: Nominated by gaurav khurana: Brijesh deb has done a very good thing of creating TTC - The test chat community where tester chat anything. He has done a full season of episodes with so many renowned names in the testing which has so many learnings for the testers. He deserves to get this award for the effort he does for the community

name: Matt Parker
note: Nominated by Duncs: Since joining our team 4 months ago, Matt has exceeded expectations of his role, demonstrating deep testing & technical knowledge as well as his leadership skills. This commitment has earned Matt the worthy promotion to QA Lead, heading up the team of Quality Advocates & establishing the culture of quality across the company. All this whilst continuing his fantastic community efforts including Diversitus (opening doors to a world of neurodiverse opportunities) and of course Staffs Tester Gathering

name: Georgia Bloyce
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for sharing her inspiring story on how to align your team on quality in the last #DojoMasterclass.

name: Francisco Valdovines
note: Nominated by Armando Cifuentes: Maybe Paco is one of the few disruptive leaders, and testers, that I have ever met. He's the kind of person you would love to work with. He's always available to help and spread his knowledge with the community. He emphasizes the human part and soft skills more than the technical things. He encourages you to be not only a better engineer but a better person. So: learn a lot from him and enjoy the moment (you'll not regret)

name: Blanca J. Moreno Gallegos
note: Nominated by Armando Cifuentes: Founder of one of the largest Spanish-speaking testing communities (QA Minds), Blanca is the person who is always available to help other people with their testing problems, mentoring the community on the best practices of testing, proposing solutions to any type, and looking for the best approaches to solve complex problems. Also, she is very active in the IT ecosystem of communities. So, if you have the opportunity to know her, believe me: you will learn a lot from her.

name: Niranjani Manoharan
note: Nominated by Jesper: Niranjani runs an awesome DevOps book club, where the books are about servant leadership, leading quality, valuable acceleration of quality and much more.

name: Nicole van der Hoeven
note: Nominated by Marie Drake: Nicole has been producing a lot of great content on performance testing. She is a developer advocate and also the co-host of k6 office hours. She recently did a meet up talk on Ministry of Testing Philippines about server side performance testing which was very informative. Her podcast episode on TestGuild with Joe Colantonio is also a great episode which I urge everyone to listen to.

name: Melissa Fisher
note: Nominated by A11y Ady: Melissa has been the inspiration behind the new book 'Testing Stories'. She has brought the community together to share their stories, inspire others and all while raising money for charity. Get a copy of the book here: https://leanpub.com/testing_stories

name: Bruce the Legend
note: Nominated by A11y Ady: Bruce supports the testing community in many ways and most recently has designed an awesome cover for Testing Stories, a book raising money for charity.

name: Sopan Sagorkar
note: Nominated by Chetan, Anuj and Darshan. Highlighted was his curiosity and depth of application knowledge. Curious and innovative in API and Mobile Test Automation. On top of his technical skills, he is a team player, working closely with developers and encouraging them to change their mindset.

name: Yashi Amola
note: Nominated by Mo Shuheb: I have worked under Ben as QA Manager and now Yashi, she reminds me so much of Ben. Yashi is a strong QA Manager as well as an extremely observant tester. She had managed to tackle test projects on 3 individuals PODs on her own before I was brought on as the second QA, she did all this whilst also running recruitment and planning out an automation strategy for the team going forward.

name: Sergei Gapanovich
note: Nominated by Butch Mayhew: Sergei has been on my team for just around 2 years now, and has risen to lead the test automation efforts on his team. When the system is changed and automation discovers a change he is gracious in calling out these changes to the team that broke it with clear examples to the team.

name: Neil Studd
note: Nominated by Deborah Reid: Hosts an awesome podcast which combines fun, testing and music. Great work and thank you :)

name: Marie Drake
note: Nominated by Deborah Reid: Gave a great talk on accessibility including how to shift it left. She included some great analogies and it was an engaging talk

name: AJ Wilson
note: Nominated by Gareth Waterhouse: AJ elevates so many people and helps give them a voice. She's so passionate about testing and quality and does so much to drive this not just in her team but with anyone interested as well.

name: Laveena Ramchandani
note: Nominated by Thomas Rinke: for helping shape wonderful conferences by reviewing all currently available #TestBash abstracts.

name: Beth Marshall
note: Nominated by Ady Stokes: Beth has brought so much to the Software Testing Bootcamp, knowledge, enthusiasm and so many practical tips. It’s been an absolute honour to work alongside her and the other trainers.

name: Simon Tomes
note: For his gargantuan efforts in blogging, community building and bringing TestBuddy to our toolset!

name: Praveen Mathew
note: Nominated by Pricilla: Always ready to help, and doing good on different community forums.

name: Stephen Mounsey
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: for helping to start and build a testing community in Newcastle by organising MOT Newcastle and also being  main artist and organizer for the Newcastle Test Atelier

name: João Proença
note: Nominated by Thomas: for his talk about costs and value of automated tests and the cognitive biases that might prevent us from deleting them.

name: Elena Bazina
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Elena really is a passionate and driven tester who is keen to help drive and transform the practices in her org.

name: Sylvia Killinen
note: Nominated by Venkat Ramakrishnan: For doing an awesome presentation on Security Testing at Ministry Of Testing, Bangalore (https://www.meetup.com/Ministry-of-Testing-Bangalore), answering all the curious questions from the attendees, and continuing to contribute to Security Testing!

name: Suman Bala
note: Nominated by Haroon Sheikh: Suman has been growing in strength since I’ve started working with her over 5 years ago. Suman has been an incredible advocate for accessibility testing specially. She’s recently been a lot more active in the testing community sharing her depth of knowledge and experience.

name: Srijana Aacharya
note: Nominated by Mukta Sharma: She is a great QA. She is a mother of a small kid. Although her post on LinkedIn are engaging but her dedication towards improving and learning herself despite being so busy with her kid and family made me interested to nominate her. I think, this little gesture of ours will motivate her and inspire her to not lose hope in her career and life.

name: Manoj Kumar
note: Nominated by Venkat Ramakrishnan: For delivering an awesome talk on Selenium 4 and Appium 2.0 at the Ministry Of Testing, Bangalore (https://www.meetup.com/Ministry-of-Testing-Bangalore) online Meetup, for which 213 people registered, and around 60 attended live!

name: Kelly Wason
note: Nominated by Jaswanth Manigundan: Kelly has been a champion in the Melbourne testing community. She has helped a lot of upcoming testers achieve their goals. Her mentorship is so selfless that she helps people without expecting anything in return. Her combined skillset with testing, development, management and coaching makes her a unique person. Thanks a lot Kelly for your amazing mentorship.

name: Danny Dainton
note: Nominated by Amruth Pillai: Danny's super hero skill is the equivalent of finding a needle in a gigantic haystack we call the Postman codebase. An eagle eye for issues, big or small. If it has even the slightest chance of affecting our end users, Danny takes the bullet for them to catch it even before it hits production.

name: Chris Forsyth
note: Nominated by Gabbi: Gives up copious personal time to run QA Beginners Club and help with MOT Manchester

name: Brian Caloz
note: Nominated by Neha Chopra: Brian has always been a well organised tester and a mentor. Testing is an art and he is a great artist with his different aspects of ensuring quality in every task he does.

name: Ady Stokes
note: Nominated by Melissa Fisher: Ady is exceptional with providing constructive feedback to testing stories submissions. We are so grateful to have you in the group.

name: Maaike Brinkhof
note: Nominated by Patrick Prill: The Queen of Grump is also an amazing tester, who doesn't hesitate to call out bullshit in the industry, making suggestions to improve. She's also willing to share her struggles, which helps people to not feel alone.

name: Louise Gibbs
note: Nominated by Peet Michielsen: Louise is an active member in the tester's community. Great sketch-noter and best question asker at (online) meet ups.

name: Lisi Hocke
note: Nominated by Patrick Prill: She's an amazing motivator in the testing community for years. With her seemingly endless and contagious enthusiasm she brought many people to follow in her footsteps and become better every day.

name: Cian Levi McCormack
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: for being one of the lead voices in MOT Newcastle and driving voice in creating Newcastle Test Atelier

name: Hannah Pretswell
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: for helping to create MOT Newcastle and pushing her self out of her comfort zone whilst also helping to create Newcastle Test Atelier. She's also been a leading voice in Scott Logics internal test community

name: Michael Allison
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: For helping set up MOT Newcastle and driving it forward along with Newcastle Test Atelier. If that wasn't enough he's also be a passionate advocate of the Sage internal test community helping it grow across products and countries

name: Gaspar Nagy
note: Nominated by Venkat Ramakrishnan: For delivering an awesome talk about BDD Examples at Ministry Of Testing, Bangalore (https://www.meetup.com/Ministry-of-Testing-Bangalore) for our monthly meetup in February 2021.

name: Craig Wylie
note: Nominated by Peet Michielsen: For organising the Ministry of Testing Edinburgh meet ups, and the online meet ups since lockdown

name: Suman Bala
note: Nominated by Yogita Lad: Most dedicated person to the testing community I have ever met. passionate about Testing and quality, speaker, trainer, motivator & mentor. Always ready to help & support despite of her busy schedule.

name: Scott Kenyon
note: Nominated by Ady Stokes: Scott has been teaching a software testing bootcamp for new to tech folks. His energy and enthusiasm show through in the sessions and his knowledge and insights are really helping the students.

name: Melissa Fisher
note: Nominated by Jesper Ottosen: A great article on Do test managers add value in agile settings? https://fishoutthebox.medium.com/do-test-managers-add-value-in-agile-settings-96f09fd4e6a1

weblinks.name: Do test managers add value in agile settings?

name: Damian Synadinos
note: Nominated by Patrick Prill: Damian’s continuous endeavor to teach people the basics about communication to make teams perform better, understand their needs and deliver what customers really want. Engaging with Damian and his work is always an enriching experience.

name: Raghav Pal
note: Nominated by Shailesh Kumar: on behalf of thousands of testers who owe him & me ..his proud student. An awesome teacher of everything re: testing/QA/DevOps. His mantra - "Never Stop Learning, sharing and helping others".

name: Heather Talbot
note: Nominated by Dan Peacock: For championing accessibility in her team since recently starting her career in testing, and designing an automated accessibility test framework.

name: Gareth Waterhouse
note: Nominated by Aaron Flynn: His valuable review comments when reviewing an article I wrote. I appreciate his time, and its definitely improved the piece.

name: Conor Fitzgerald
note: Nominated by Venkat Ramakrishnan: For giving a great talk on how Kanban helps in Software Testing for Ministry Of Testing, Bangalore (https://www.meetup.com/Ministry-of-Testing-Bangalore) at our monthly Meetup in January 2021. Thanks Conor!

name: Margaret Dineen
note: Nominated by Conor Fitzgerald for creating a valuable podcast for the community - Quality Coaching Roadshow.

name: Theodora - Maria Dascalu
note: Nominated by Richard Durham: Theo asks a lot of questions, of everyone regardless of grade/position. She challenges all assumptions. With Theo around everyone around her learns the things they thought they knew because she keeps digging until the answer is clear. Every team needs a Theo!

name: Anne-Marie Charrett
note: Nominated by Conor Fitzgerald for creating a valuable podcast for the community - Quality Coaching Roadshow.

name: John Paul McGee
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: for creating and pushing himself to talk at local events and then at Test bash. He's also been instrumental in driving an internal test community at Sage.

name: Crystal Preston-Watson
note: Nominated by Elizabeth Fiennes: Crystal is an accessibility advocate and caller out of what good looks like.

name: Robert Meaney
note: Nominated by Conor Fitzgerald: for his willingness to share his knowledge on the 'ilities and for developing models that make it easy to understand.'

name: Kay Coombes
note: Nominated by Russell Craxford: 'for taking time out of her day job as a tester to speak at Newcastle University to promote testing as a career path to computer science graduates and make testing a first class software citizen

name: Dimitri Harding
note: Nominated by Julia Pottinger: 'For his first conference presentation at @testguilds last week. He did a great presentation on Data Driven Testing : Increasing Test Coverage and Reducing Test Code. Dimitri is someone that helps me out with complex problems from time to time and I'm really happy and proud of him for sharing his knowledge with the TestGuild community. And he did great '

name: Heather Reid
note: Nominated by Conor Fitzgerald for the great work she does with the Community through her role with the Ministry of Testing.

name: Kinga Witko
note: Never fails to find bugs in each and every piece of software she uses! A wonderful tester and talented conference speaker! I was very honoured to work with her for a short time at NVM!

name: Del Dewar
note: Co-founding member of the 'Grumpsters' but again one of the nicest people ever. Always brings insightful knowledge to each conversation. Still love the unrecorded Huib Schoots pronunciation.

name: Yevheniia Hlovatska
note: Yevheniia has been sharing experience of using a whole team approach to quality to avoid the QA Bottleneck and find bugs early.

weblinks.name: Team as a Key to “Agile” Quality

name: Sidharth Shukla
note: Nominated by Arun Motoori: 'for his contributions at https://automationreinvented.blogspot.com. He is helping a lot of people clearing the interviews'

name: Constance Armitage
note: Constance is such a wonderful human!! I am in absolute awe of all her artwork, it's incredible!! The artwork for the Testbash adventures is something you just need to check out!!

weblinks.name: The Artful Tester – Episode Two – Trip To TestBash Brighton
My TestBash Adventure by Conny Armitage

name: Patrick Prill
note: Self-proclaimed 'Grumpster' but is, in fact, one of the nicest, warmest and funniest people you will ever meet. A super talented tester with an incredible amount of knowledge!

name: Bill Matthews
note: Bill is one of those people that never fails to impress you - His talks are informative, engaging and enlightening. Breaks down super technical topics in an easily digestible way. Also a wonderful human!!

name: Dino Kacavenda
note: Dino has written an excellent article, '12 Tips for Writing Better Automated Tests'. I especially like number 8 'Avoid magic numbers or strings'.

weblinks.name: 12 Tips for Writing Better Automated Tests

name: Chris Gissing
note:
Nominated by Robert Hyde: Today's nomination is a sad one indeed, I will be honest it has taken me a while to put this together because it is still very raw.

Today's honorary nomination is for Munichbeer, Chris, who we recently lost way before his time.  While he had moved on from his direct testing days a while ago I feel it only approprpriate to put Chris on the list for all the lives he changed.  Not only did he help me become the engineer I am today but also he helped so many other engineers.

Chris was a great person who filled a room just by being in it, a great parent who would always be there for his family, an amazing manager who cared about everyone and finally a brilliant friend.  I will definitely miss you Chris and our times chatting away/working together.

I know this cannot even come close to giving credit to the legend but it is my small way of remembering you and the way you changed things for me

name: James Sheasby Thomas
note: An Agile Testing and Web Accessibility Advocate, James posts excellent content on their website and joins in the community discussion on the MoT Club. Jame's excellent article on Crafting a Browser Matrix is an oldie but a goldie and wroth checking out.

name: Dennis Martinez
note: Dennis shares his experience of Test Automation in a weekly blog series Dev Tester. Covering topics on frontend with Test Cafe and Backend API testing. Articles often feature Test Cafe, a topic Dennis has also written a book on!

weblinks.name: Dev Tester: Weekly articles about automated testing

name: Ronald Cummings-John
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: 'Ron is one of the best speakers on the circuit, and his passion for driving quality across an organisation is second to none. The Leading Quality book is also fast becoming to go-to book for quality leaders'

name: Yogita K Lad
note: Yogita has jumped into learning all about software testing with fantastic enthusiasm. I love reading her blog and can't wait to see where she is a year from now.

name: Brittany Stewart
note: Nominated by Julia Pottinger: 'She converted our company's test strategy into a mindmap that is sooo easy to use and have been key in helping other persons on our team use mindmapping in testing. It's been great.'

name: Chris Armstrong
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: 'Chris is one of the most passionate and driven test leaders I know and also one of the most supportive peers you could ever ask for. A team is better with Chris in it!'

weblinks.name: Chris Armstrong – Posting about Testing, Agility, Leadership, Mental Health, Quality Practices and More

name: Duncan Nisbet
note: Nominated by Matthew Parker: 'He’s quietly been a huge part of moving the testing community forward for years. His passion for learning new things and continuous personal development permeates to everyone he engages with, domain newbies and old experienced hands alike.'

name: Emma Keaveny
note: Nominated by Deborah Reid: 'Always smiley, positive and passionate about testing. Her talk on dark patterns still resonates and her charisma at events is something lots of us are missing at the moment!'

name: Jessica Ingrassellino
note: For her ceaseless desire to improve, not only in her work, but the lives and work of others. She has brought tech education to people of all ages, with her writing, tutorials and boundless energy

name: Krishnanand B
note: Nominated by Sudarshan GS: 'He’s been instrumental in the success of our organization, helping create scalable automation solutions for different clients over the years. He also helped the folks in the organization to scale up.'

name: Claire Reckless
note: Nominated by Shey: 'Claire wrote The One Page Test Plan on MoT in 2016 which remains an informative and relevant reference five years on.'

name: Jesper Ottosen
note: Nominated by Michael: 'Jesper wrote a great post about continuing to talk about making the testing smarter and not single out that this is for testers only.'

name: David Laing
note: David has been working hard to get his passion for testing back and I managed to persuade him to read Explore It to give him ideas. He’s now defining a new Exploratory testing process for our internal release testing. Great work Dave!

name: Elizabeth Fiennes
note: Nominated by Danny Dainton: A wonderful human, always a pleasure to be around her. Love hearing her talks and learning from her wealth of experience in the Testing industry!!

name: Darshit Shah
note: Nominated by Pooja Gaur: 'Darshit is one of the most creative dedicated QA engineers, an enthusiastic professional, Analytical, solutions-oriented, and highly motivated with excellent testing skills. He has all-rounded skills. He is a great Mentor, Leader, always help to design as a potential academic and career path for youngsters which help hundreds of aspirants on learning about testing. He is the founder of Be Simple (on Facebook) and has just completed his portfolio website and share his knowledge on medium.'

name: Brittany Walthall
note: Nominated by Allen Helton: 'She designs, writes stories, tests, and automates - all with a smile on her face. Our team couldn't operate without her. Her drive is rivaled by no one.'

name: Gita Malinovska
note: Nominated by Adam Leon Smith: 'for being a great test manager, an inspiration to her diverse team, keeping all senior stakeholders feet held to the fire, as well finding the time to organise BCS SIGIST events in the background'

name: Melissa Fisher
note: Melissa has brought together a fantastic group of Testers from the community to write a charity eBook of Testing Stories.

name: Erkki Antonkov
note: Nominated by Shey Crompton: 'Erkki is an awesome contributor to the community. He's always supportive and is one of the most chilled people I know.'

name: Tristan Lombard
note: Nominated by Antonella Scaravilli: 'Tristan very active in our community and he helps make it more diverse and inclusive'

name: Tea Pot
note: Nominated by Adesinafaizat: '@J_teapot is a tester that has been active for over 15 years and have lead many successful projects. He has coached, mentored and inspired alot of young minds towards Testing ( I inclusive) even experts as well. He is giving to the profession more than he is getting back which is why he set up http://naijatestcrowd.com  (@NaijaTestCrowd) to enable newbies have access to materials that can make their journey into testing easy and fun. He's selfless person that needs to be awarded over and over again for his passion towards Testing.'

name: Uros Stanisic
note: Nominated by @WhitehatQa: 'Inspirational leader. Always there to help, keep the testers from the company as a small community. Shares his knowledge with the community on Conferences.'

name: Venkat Ramakrishnan
note: Nominated by Sylvia Killinen: 'He's not only a tester, but a community organizer who puts together events and discussion with Ministry of Test'

name: Gitte Klitgaard
note: Nominated by Tobias Geyer: 'for being a force for good in the agile and software testing community. No matter if she's leading by example to encourage everyone to let their full selves show or by helping to make software testing conferences a safer place - everything is better with Gitte being there.'

name: Peter Schrijver
note: For continuing to introduce me and the rest of the world, to 5 new blogs every day - One's that I would have never have found

name: Lee Marshall
note: Nominated by Dan Billing: 'for determination and self reflection at a time of huge change and challenge'

weblinks.name: The Priate Tester - Sailing against the testing establishment

name: Dave Oxley
note: Nominated by Simon Prior: Although not technically still a tester, Dave’s mentoring and guidance over the years really helped me move into testing and make a success of it. He’s to blame for my relentless passion for quality!

name: Marty McGee
note: An SDET who enjoys automation, Marty shares his expertise and sense of humour on Twitter and his Blog.

name: Andrew Fraser
note: Nominated by Shey: He's always supportive and goes out of his way to help the community.

name: Conrad Braam
note: Conrad is super active on the Club and Twitter, contributing his wealth of knowledge. He recently joined us on the Testers Hangout and shared his experience of working through lock-down.

name: Srinivas Kadiyala
note: Nominated by Bill Matthews: for always asking questions & seeking to better understand  testing & technology and sharing his experiences and findings.

name: Christian Baumann
note: Nominated by Violetta Zhdanovich: 'He's a tester I look up to. Christian is an explorer, an investigator, a learner, a teacher, a great communicator and a team player. He's inspiring'

name: Conor Fitzgerald
note: Nominated by Michael: 'Conor is an active member of the test community and his talks covering Kanban are a great help for those looking at Kanban and Agile.'

name: Katrina Clokie
note: Katrina’s testing pathways are such great resources to help the test community learn different areas of testing!

name: Emna Ayadi
note: Nominated by Jasper: 'a true community hero - not only for the sfax meetups, but for global online coffee sesisons in a pandemic. And starting a snack exchange too'

name: Zubair Haque
note: Zubair has been a guest on the Test Guild podcast talking about testing performence of Microservice. He has years of performence testing exprience, and shares his knowledge with the community on Medium.

weblinks.name: ScalaTest Performance Testing Microservices with Zubair Haque

name: Josh Grant
note: Josh shares his testing thoughts, recently musing about a concept dear to my heat, Software that is good because it does what we expect.

weblinks.name: Twitter Thread: Software that works as expected

name: Guna Petrova
note: Nominated by Bill Matthews: for her unceasing enthusiasm, for testing, and being an awesome tester. And not least for being open and welcoming to all she meets.

name: Arun Motoori
note: Nominated by Sanjay Kumar: His passion to share knowledge help millions of people to build their career. Arun is an asset to Testing community. A great mentor, Leader and Trainer.
